burnout_education.title: The Three Dimensions of Burnout
burnout_education.content:
Burnout has three key dimensions:
1. Emotional Exhaustion - Feeling drained and depleted
2. Depersonalization - Cynicism and detachment from work
3. Reduced Personal Accomplishment - Feeling ineffective

Recognizing these signs early is key to prevention.

burnout_education.title: Office Syndrome Prevention
burnout_education.content:
Office syndrome refers to health problems from prolonged desk work:
- Neck and shoulder pain
- Lower back pain
- Carpal tunnel syndrome
- Eye strain
- Poor circulation

Prevention: Regular movement breaks, proper ergonomics, stretching.

stress_management_techniques.name: Box Breathing
stress_management_techniques.description: Breathe in for 4 counts, hold for 4, exhale for 4, hold for 4. Repeat.

stress_management_techniques.name: 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding
stress_management_techniques.description: Identify 5 things you see, 4 you can touch, 3 you hear, 2 you smell, 1 you taste
instructions: Look around and name 5 things you can see
Notice 4 things you can physically feel
Listen for 3 things you can hear

stress_management_techniques.name: Progressive Muscle Relaxation
stress_management_techniques.description: Systematically tense and relax muscle groups
instructions: Start with your feet, tense muscles for 5 seconds
Move up through legs, abdomen, arms, shoulders, face

stress_management_techniques.name: Pomodoro Technique
stress_management_techniques.description: Work for 25 minutes, break for 5. Repeat 4 times, then longer break.
instructions: Set timer for 25 minutes of focused work
Use breaks for movement and rest

ergonomic_tips.description: Your monitor should be about an arm's length away, with the top at or slightly below eye level
ergonomic_tips.impact: Reduces neck strain and eye fatigue

ergonomic_tips.description: Adjust chair height so feet rest flat on floor (or footrest) with knees at 90-degree angle
Keep wrists straight and neutral when typing, elbows at 90-100 degrees
ergonomic_tips.impact: Prevents carpal tunnel and wrist strain

ergonomic_tips.description: Sit back in chair with lumbar support, shoulders relaxed
Position monitor to avoid glare from windows, use proper task lighting
Every 20 minutes, look at something 20 feet away for 20 seconds

workplace_boundaries.description: Define when your workday starts and ends. Communicate these boundaries.
workplace_boundaries.why_it_matters: Prevents work from consuming all your time and energy

workplace_boundaries.description: Don't be always available. It's okay to respond in the morning.
workplace_boundaries.why_it_matters: Allows for genuine rest and recovery

workplace_boundaries.description: It's okay to decline additional tasks when your plate is full.
Breaks aren't optional or selfish - they're necessary for performance.
workplace_boundaries.why_it_matters: Maintains energy and focus throughout the day
